soc.server

Class SOCServerMessageDispatcher

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.server.SOCServerMessageDispatcher
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SOCMessageDispatcher

    class SOCServerMessageDispatcher
extends java.lang.Object
implements SOCMessageDispatcher
    Server class to dispatch all inbound messages within a SOCServer. Sole exception: The first message from a client is dispatched by SOCServer.processFirstCommand(SOCMessage, Connection) instead.

    For more details, see main handler method dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection).

    Once server is initialized, call setServer(SOCServer, SOCServerMessageHandler, SOCGameListAtServer) before calling dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection).

    Since:
    2.0.00
    Author:
    Jeremy D Monin <jeremy@nand.net>

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCServerMessageDispatcher

        public SOCServerMessageDispatcher()
        Create a new SOCServerMessageDispatcher. Takes no parameters because the server and dispatcher constructors can't both call each other. Be sure to call setServer(SOCServer, SOCServerMessageHandler, SOCGameListAtServer) before dispatching.

    • Method Detail

      • setServer

        public void setServer(SOCServer srv,
                      SOCServerMessageHandler srvHandler,
                      SOCGameListAtServer gameList)
               throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                      java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Set our SOCServer and game list references, necessary before dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection) can be called.
        Parameters:
        srv - This dispatcher's server
        srvHandler - Server message handler for srv
        gameList - Game list for srv
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If srv, srvHandler, or gameList are null
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - If setServer(..) has already been called

      • dispatchFirst

        public void dispatchFirst(SOCMessage mes,
                          Connection con)
        Specified by:
        dispatchFirst in interface SOCMessageDispatcher

      • dispatch

        public void dispatch(SOCMessage mes,
                     Connection con)
              throws java.lang.IllegalStateException
        Process an inbound message from a client.

        For general messages which aren't a SOCMessageForGame, calls SOCServerMessageHandler.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection).

        For SOCMessageForGames, calls that game's GameMessageHandler.dispatch(SOCGame, SOCMessageForGame, Connection) method (probably SOCGameMessageHandler.dispatch(SOCGame, SOCMessageForGame, Connection)). If the dispatcher doesn't recognize or handle the message, it returns false, and the message falls through to the non-SOCMessageForGame handler SOCServerMessageHandler.dispatch(SOCMessage, Connection).

        General notes:

        Remove a queued incoming message from a client, and handle it. Called from the message handler thread of Connection.

        Do not block or sleep in any derived code because this is single-threaded. Any slow or lengthy work for a message should be done on other threads.

        dispatch(..) must catch any exception thrown by conditions or bugs in server or gameName code it calls.

        The first message from a peer is dispatched by SOCMessageDispatcher.dispatchFirst(SOCMessage, Connection).

        Security Note: When there is a choice, always use local information over information from the message. For example, use the nickname from the connection to get the player information rather than the player information from the message. This makes it harder to send false messages making players do things they didn't want to do.

        Specified by:
        dispatch in interface SOCMessageDispatcher
        Parameters:
        mes - Message from the client. Will never be null.
        con - Connection (peer) sending this message. Will never be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if not ready to dispatch because setServer(SOCServer, SOCServerMessageHandler, SOCGameListAtServer) hasn't been called.
